Posts.Content: Saw my South Carolina urologist/surgeon today regarding the recent rise in uPSA from non-detectable (<0.015) to 0.040. This rise began about three years after surgery and appears to show a PSADT of about 6-7 months. Even with Gleason 8 pathology, the doctor was very positive about my situation in light of three three year non detectable PSA levels and relatively slow doubling time. He said there is the possibility that some benign prostate tissue may have been left behind at the prostate/bladder juncture. He prescribed Finasteride to see if it would knock down the PSA level. He said the drug has shown to be useful whether the rise is from benign or cancer cells. He told be not to worry about this as either way we will likely be here gen years from now discussing these same issues. Anyone else have a similar experience or wish to comment on the above. I plan to be back in New York in about a month and have an appointment scheduled with a RO to get his perspective.

Posts.Content: I would recommend a 3T MTI at a prostate cancer center before the biopsy to provide a target area to biopsy along with the standard test grid. If the 3T MRI suggests cancer, the biopsy can be done the next day. The last thing you want is to go though a biopsy while having cancer and come up with negative results because they didn't biopsy the right location and lose valuable time before another biopsy finds the cancer.

Posts.Content: I would recommend a 3T MTI at a prostate cancer center before the biopsy to provide a target area to biopsy along with the standard test grid. If the 3T MRI suggests cancer, the biopsy can be done the next day. The last thing you want is to go though a biopsy while having cancer and come up with negative results because they didn't biopsy the right location and lose valuable time before another biopsy finds the cancer.

Posts.Title: How important is a 3T MRI? My experience.

Posts.Content: The importance of the 3T MRI? Several urologist kept telling me I was at low risk for prostate cancer with no family history, normal DREs relatively low PSA for my age and several urinary infections that temporarily raised PSA values. I finally got one urologist to refer me to NY University for the MRI. It found one small tumor. The next day the biopsy was done using the MRI data to locate and target the tumor. They took two biopsies at that location as well as the standard twelve grid biopsy of the entire prostate. Only one of the two "targeted" biopsies hit the tumor and all of the standard twelve grid biopsies were also negative. To repeat, 13 out of 14 biopsy locations were negative. Hence, without the MRI my Gleason 8 cancer would have been surely missed. The after surgery pathology report showed two additional tumors, Gleason 7 and 6. Need I say more about the chances of missing aggressive prostate cancers with hit and miss, blind biopsies. To prove my point, I had one jackass urologist that said he was so good at DREs that he never missed a cancer! Another jackass assured me that if he missed a tumor with a negative biopsy result, it meant I had a very small tumor that would not be advanced or life threatening! Everyone wants to hear they are fine. They think they have a great doctor. I now wish I would have found out about the 3T MRI imaging a year sooner and improved my outcome.

Posts.Content: Talked this issue over with my internist. She thought a repeat test would be useful and may help put my mind at ease. The repeat uPSA value can back at 0.021. This test was two months after the 0.023 result from the same lab and test procedure. As the result was a bit lower rather than higher, I guess it has put my mind at ease. The doctor thinks I should repeat it again in four months. All this makes one wonder what is the overall +/- accuracy of the uPSA test and how often/does the test equipment need to be calibrated.

Posts.Title: Any reason for concern?

Posts.Content: Did they tell you of what this "nodule" is composed? If I had a nodule on my prostate for three years, I'd be arraigning for an MRI guided biopsy to put my mind at ease. That is, unless they had a very convincing story as to what was found by the MRI and I was personally able to verify their story in medical literature available on the internet. Neither the MRI or the biopsy are much of a big deal especially when you consider your life is at stake. The more information you have the better off you are. I may be somewhat of an alarmist having had a friend who died from PC before his 40th birthday, leaving a wife and teenage daughters. He never had a DRE or PSA test before finding blood in his urine and by then it was way too late to help him.

Posts.Title: Should I get another 3T MRI

Posts.Content: Every test has an accuracy band of plus or minus some amount. I don't know if you have listed ever PSA blood test result you have received since the surgery to be able to see a trend in your PSA readings. It is very difficult to find out what the true accuracy of their testing is or how often the equipment is calibrated. I have been told by LabCorp that they do not round up the result so that 0.010 and 0.019 are both reported as 0.01. That information is about two years old and I can not vouch for that person's correctness on the subject. I don't think I would worry about it unless I saw a clear trend where each test result was higher then the previous one regardless of that actually value. Ie 0.05, 0.06, 0.07, 0.09 would alert me as much as 0.1, 0.2, 0.3 ect.

Posts.Title: Best point to start SRT?

Posts.Content: Thanks for that information guys. I am located one and a half hours north of Albany, New York, near Chestertown. I had my robotic prostatectomy at NY university hospital (five hours from home) and had severe complications so I am reluctant to go back to them. Two days after surgery the major incision at the umbilical opened and I believed it was infectious. I received poor response at the doctors office as the surgeon and staff kept saying it was not an infection every day they dressed the three inch deep wound until day seven when the catheter was removed. It took three months to resolve the Staph infection and the wound to close without their help. Six months after surgery I required emergency surgery for removal of a nearly two liter size lymphocele that was infected with Strep and compressing my bladder. I am now left with an extremely large incisional hernia. The hernia repair would require a major open surgery at a "world class" facility, according to several doctors. My conclusion is that even if the surgeon you decide on at a teaching hospital does the prostate removal, there are many students doing other tasks like lymph node removal ect. that can put you at increased risk for major life threatening complications.

Posts.Title: Complications from My Robotic Surgery - Things you should be aware of

Posts.Content: My purpose here is not to scare anyone from their choice of treatment options but to make them aware of possible complications and a better advocate for themselves. Believe it or not, you may know your body better than your doctor. About three days after surgery at NYU hospital in Sept 2013, I developed a fever just under the cutoff for calling in to the doctor 101F. As you are on pain and antibiotic meds your temperature will be suppressed. I called the hotline anyway and was told not to worry but call back if you surpass 101F which it never did. As I live 200 miles north of NYC I had retained a hotel near NYU for ten days in the event a complication should occur. As it turned out the large incision at the umbilicus where the prostate gland was pulled through, had opened. When I presented myself first thing Monday morning at the doctors offices I at first was treated very poorly as to why I was there and then their response was that my wife should be able to dress my wound. When they saw that the wound was open and you can look into the deep hole in my body their attitude changed. However, they kept telling me the wound wasn't infected as the drainage was clear but since I was on Cipro as the cath was still in place they were wrong. Every morning I went to the doctors office and was told the same thing (no infection) as they had to pack a wet dressing deep into the wound. They had to arrange for a nurse to come to my home each day to dress the wound and allow it to heal from the bottom up. Once an incision opens it is considered a dirty wound that must be allowed to heal on its own. This took three months to heal and when I got home my internist changed the antibiotic after lab tests showed a staph infection that proved very difficult to resolve. I took antibiotics for nearly three months to clear the infection that would return in three days after completing each course of drugs. The problem here was that even though I felt I had a wound infection and kept telling them so from right after surgery, no doctor would believed me until I completed a round of drugs and smelly yellow fluid squirted out into my doctor's face as she pressed around the open wound that at least three or four doctors and many nurses said was not infected. Now that they had proof, they could then collect the yellow fluid to send to the lab and determine the best antibiotic treatment. Finally clear of infection, at my urging, my doctor ordered a CAT scan to see that there was no internal abcess and make sure all was well. The scan showed a huge mass in my abdominal area that the radiologist who read the scan thought was cancer. My doctor thought I was history. It was nearly two liters in size, compressing and displacing my bladder to the left. After much worry a good general surgeon I went to said it wasn't cancer but rather a very large lynphocele caused by removing a lymph node and not having a proper seal to stop the leakage of fluid. This process developed a cyst with many cambers containing fluid. Even though you may pick a fine surgeon to perform the robotic surgery he may be training others who may perform the lesser tasks like removing and sealing off lymph nodes. This may be especially true in teaching hospitals. I was told the lymphocele could be left in place unless it presented a problem. Some research literature states that small lymphoceles about the size of golf balls are quite common after cancer surgery but go undetected unless found as a result of imaging tests for some unrelated problem. About two months later I developed a very high fever 103+F and was rushed to a hospital and treated as a septis patient, a life threatening blood infection. I was put on every interveinous drug they had on the shelf and nothing lowered my fever. It turned out that Strep bacteria had invaded the lymph fluid in the lymphocele and I needed immediate surgery as drugs cannot get to the infected fluid. This was a very big surgery and a difficult recovery with a large incision from my umbilical to nearly my penis. Then after about six months recovery from these issues I developed a very big incisional hernia with small intestine bulging about four or five inches out from my stomach. The surgeon said it was probably a result of the tissue having been weakened from the prior infection. He wants me to undergo a four hour surgery to repair the hernia by patching in some pig skin at the defect. I am reluctant to do this as there is about a 40% chance it will fail and the hernia will return. I wear an elastic wrap to somewhat hide and protect the hernia. The good news is that my PSA at two years post op is 0.00! Although all of the many doctors and radiologists I saw steered my toward surgery due to my age and general good health, I may have been better served or had an easier experience had I chosen another treatment or maybe a local surgeon rather than a "world class" university hospital.

Posts.Title: Maybe I'm too analytical, but I'll ask this question anyway.

Posts.Content: My question does not pertain to how a Gleason score is determined, that's defined in every PCa website. My question is whether a tumor with Gleason 4 or 5 cancer cells are a result of Gleason 3 cells that have existed for a longer time and matured into a more aggressive cancer. Or are they different types of prostate cancer that are more aggressive than others. I realize the the more the prostate cancer cell looks less like a prostate tissue cell, the higher the Gleason score. But what makes them be more aggressive?

Posts.Content: My question does not pertain to how a Gleason score is determined, that's defined in every PCa website. My question is whether a tumor with Gleason 4 or 5 cancer cells are a result of Gleason 3 cells that have existed for a longer time and matured into a more aggressive cancer. Or are they different types of prostate cancer that are more aggressive than others. I realize the the more the prostate cancer cell looks less like a prostate tissue cell, the higher the Gleason score. But what makes them be more aggressive?

Posts.Title: PSA test frequency covered under Medicare

Posts.Content: He needs to get a "good" 3T MRI and tell him to keep still. That's really not that hard to do! Below is what I recently posted of my MRI experience on another thread. The importance of the 3T MRI. Several urologist kept telling me I was at low risk for prostate cancer and normal DREs. I finally got one urologist to refer me to NY University for the MRI. It found one small tumor. The next day the biopsy was done using the MRI data to locate and target the tumor. They took two biopsies at that location as well as the standard twelve grid biopsy of the entire prostate. Only one of the two "targeted" biopsies hit the tumor and all of the standard twelve grid biopsies were also negative. To repeat, 13 out of 14 biopsy locations were negative. Hence, without the MRI my Gleason 8 cancer would have been surely missed. The after surgery pathology report showed two additional tumors, Gleason 7 and 6. Need I say more about the chances of missing aggressive prostate cancers with hit and miss, blind biopsies. To prove my point, I had one jackass urologist that said he was so good at DREs that he never missed a cancer! Another jackass assured me that if he missed a tumor with a negative biopsy result, it meant I had a very small tumor that would not be advanced or life threatening! Everyone wants to hear they are fine. They think they have a great doctor. I now wish I would have found out about the 3T MRI imaging a year sooner and improved my outcome.
